p: Fecundity increased significantly with body size but was not explicitly impacted by habitat type (GLM, Maternal body size: mean slope ± SE = 1754.7 ± 191.3, P<0.001; Habitat: parameter estimate ± SE = 1394.0 ± 1255.3, P = 0.274, Fig 7). However, due to differences in maternal body size, fecundity was higher in the mangroves (mean no. eggs/ individual ± SE = 15215.9 ± 1027.6, Fig 7) than in the mixed marsh (mean no. eggs/ individual ± SE = 6649.7 ± 404.9, Fig 7).
